<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Non-cash
amounts have been excluded. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-
bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(2)</FONT></DT><DD 
style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Based
on Company interest production volumes. See "Basis of Presentation" section in 
the following&nbsp;MD&amp;A. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-
bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(3)</FONT></DT><DD 
style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Before
transportation costs, royalties and commodity derivative instruments. 
</FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(4)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-
family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">These
non-GAAP measures may not be directly comparable to similar measures presented 
by other entities. See "Non-GAAP Measures" section in the 
following&nbsp;MD&amp;A. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>2&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=3,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=480564,FOLIO='2',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]CA16301A.;7',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_cc16301_1_3"> </A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"black" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:arial;" -->
</FONT> <FONT SIZE=5>PRESIDENT'S MESSAGE </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Through the second quarter of 2015, 
Enerplus continued to focus on operational execution under a disciplined capital
program. We delivered production growth, improved cost
performance and maintained a strong financial position. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Production
volumes grew by 7% quarter over quarter to 107,429&nbsp;BOE per day. This growth
was primarily driven by increased activity in North Dakota, where production 
averaged approximately
27,100&nbsp;BOE per day, up over 25% from the first quarter of 2015. We also saw
growth from our gas portfolio with our Canadian Deep Basin and Marcellus assets 
showing production increases over the
first quarter of 2015. Our production mix was essentially unchanged from the 
previous quarter, with crude oil and natural gas liquids accounting for 43% 
of&nbsp;production. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result of continued operational outperformance, we are increasing our average 
annual production guidance for both liquids and gas to 100,000-104,000&nbsp;BOE 
per day from
97,000-103,000&nbsp;BOE per day. We expect approximately 44,000-
46,000&nbsp;barrels per day of crude oil and natural gas liquids. This guidance 
includes year to date divestments of approximately
1,900&nbsp;BOE per&nbsp;day. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
spent $148&nbsp;million in our core areas during the quarter, and are on track 
to meet our annual capital spending guidance of $540&nbsp;million, despite the 
weak Canadian dollar. Approximately
75% of spending in the quarter was directed to our North Dakota properties. In 
total we drilled 7.8&nbsp;net wells and brought 22&nbsp;net wells on-stream 
across our portfolio in the
second&nbsp;quarter. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Both
operating costs and G&amp;A expenses for the quarter came in lower than 
forecast, at $7.85 per BOE and $2.03 per BOE, respectively. Based on our cost 
savings realized to date and our increased
production target, we are decreasing our annual operating cost guidance to $9.25
per BOE from $9.75 per BOE and our G&amp;A expense guidance to $2.25 per BOE 
from $2.40 per BOE, representing a combined
decrease of $0.65&nbsp;per&nbsp;BOE. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Funds
flow increased by 47% to $160&nbsp;million from the first quarter. This was 
largely a result of higher production, lower costs and improved crude oil 
prices, and despite slightly weaker gas
pricing. Funds flow was also supported by our hedging program which generated 
gains of $73&nbsp;million during the second&nbsp;quarter. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
incurred a non-cash asset impairment charge in the quarter of $497&nbsp;million.
Under U.S.&nbsp;GAAP we are required to use twelve month trailing average prices
to determine impairment, and
consequently the impairment reflects the low commodity prices in the fourth 
quarter of 2014 and the first half of&nbsp;2015. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During
the quarter, we closed our previously announced non-core asset sales, along with
the sale of additional minor non-core properties for proceeds of 
$188&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our
focus on cost control, strong 2015 hedge position, divestment proceeds, and 
disciplined capital spending have helped preserve our strong financial position.
We ended the quarter with an improved
trailing debt to funds flow ratio of 1.6&nbsp;times, down from 1.7&nbsp;times in
the first quarter of 2015. At June&nbsp;30, 2015, we were approximately 8% drawn
on our $1&nbsp;billion credit
facility. Following the next scheduled repayment of our senior notes in 
October&nbsp;2015 of US$10.8&nbsp;million, we have no scheduled debt repayments 
until June of&nbsp;2017. </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>

CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=41391,FOLIO='3',FILE='DISK132:

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ce16301_1_4"> </A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"black" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:arial;" -->
</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Production and Capital Spending  </B></FONT></P>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="39%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="CENTER" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;"><B>Three months ended June&nbsp;30, 
2015</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=4 ALIGN="CENTER" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;"><B>Six months ended June&nbsp;30, 
2015</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="39%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">*</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Wells
drilled during the quarter that are pending potential completion/tie-in or 
abandonment as at June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-
family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">**</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Total
wells brought on-stream during the quarter regardless of when they 
were&nbsp;drilled. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-
9pt;'><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">***</FONT></DT><DD 
style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Table
may not add due to rounding. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Asset Activity  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We re-established production growth 
in North Dakota in the second quarter of 2015. Production from Fort Berthold 
averaged approximately 27,100&nbsp;BOE per
day during the quarter, up over 25% from the first quarter of 2015. We drilled 
5.5&nbsp;net wells in Fort Berthold with 9.2&nbsp;net wells brought on-stream 
during the quarter for a total capital
outlay of $111&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
continue to run a one-rig drilling program as we work through our inventory of 
drilled uncompleted wells at Fort Berthold and expect to drill approximately 
8&nbsp;net wells in the second half of
the year. We are ahead of schedule on our 2015 completions activity. During the 
first six months of 2015 we brought approximately 13&nbsp;net wells on stream. 
We expect to bring up to
10&nbsp;additional net wells on stream during the second half of the year. This 
activity is broadly weighted towards the third quarter and we expect production 
growth through the remainder of the
year. Our high intensity completion design continues to yield excellent results.
The average initial 30&nbsp;day production rate (IP30) of our operated on-stream
wells in the quarter was over
2,000&nbsp;BOE per day, exceeding our high end type curve. We continue to see 
improved well costs with current costs down over 20% from 2014&nbsp;levels. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
the Marcellus, continued low levels of spending ($12.6&nbsp;million in the 
second quarter) led to 0.7&nbsp;net wells drilled and 3.2&nbsp;net wells on-
stream. Despite the reduced activity,
well outperformance resulted in production of 201&nbsp;MMcf per day during the 
second quarter, a modest increase from the previous quarter. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
the Deep Basin, we drilled three excellent wells at our Ansell pad. The average 
peak 30&nbsp;day production rate for a well on the pad was approximately 
10&nbsp;MMcf per day, on trend with our
high end type&nbsp;curve. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>4&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=5,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=525612,FOLIO='4',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]CE16301A.;13',USER='EREED',CD=';6-AUG-2015;20:11' -->
<A NAME="page_ce16301_1_5"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Crude Oil&nbsp;&amp; Natural Gas 
Pricing  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The West Texas Intermediate (WTI) 
benchmark price for crude oil increased by 19% quarter-over-quarter to average 
US$57.94 per barrel in the second quarter. The
strength in WTI prices combined with the narrowing of crude oil differentials in
both Canada and the U.S.&nbsp;resulted in a 32% improvement in the selling price
for our crude oil compared to the
previous quarter. The average realized sales price for our crude oil was $58.26 
per barrel during the quarter with crude oil properties generating approximately
90% of our corporate netback. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>On
the natural gas side, both AECO and NYMEX weakened from the previous quarter due
to continued high production and increased storage levels across the continent. 
In the Marcellus, our realized
differential widened US$0.07 per Mcf from the previous quarter to average 
US$1.39 per Mcf. Overall, as a result of lower benchmark pricing and continued 
pricing weakness in the Marcellus producing
region, our realized sales price for gas fell by 19% compared to the previous 
quarter to average $2.09&nbsp;per&nbsp;Mcf. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
continued to add to our commodity hedge position for both 2015 and 2016. For the
second half of 2015, we have an average of 11,250&nbsp;barrels per day of crude 
oil hedged (representing
approximately 35% of our expected crude oil production net of royalties) at an 
average floor price of US$84.58 per barrel through a combination of swaps and 
three way collar structures. For 2016, we
have an average of 11,000&nbsp;barrels per day of crude oil hedged (representing
approximately 34% of our expected crude oil production net of royalties) at an 
average floor price of US$64.35 per
barrel through a combination of swaps and three way collar structures. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
have also added to our NYMEX gas hedging position. For the second half of 2015, 
we are swapped on an average of 128&nbsp;MMcf per day at an average price of 
US$3.82 per Mcf, representing
approximately 47% of our forecasted natural gas production after royalties. For 
2016, we have 25&nbsp;MMcf per day, or 9% of our forecasted natural gas 
production after royalties, hedged through
three-way collars with an average floor price of US$3.00&nbsp;per&nbsp;Mcf. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Outlook  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We delivered another quarter of 
strong operating results. On the back of this operational momentum and improved
cost efficiencies, we are increasing our 2015
production guidance and reducing our operating and G&amp;A expense guidance. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
continue to navigate through this challenging commodity price environment with a
strong balance sheet and hedging program that will support our funds flow. We 
remain focused on driving improvement
in our operational efficiencies through both reducing our cost structures and 
optimizing well performance. Above all, the low commodity prices have not 
stopped us from committing the time and
resources to ensure safe, responsible and sustainable operations across 
our&nbsp;business. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>
<IMG SRC="g208556.jpg" ALT="GRAPHIC" WIDTH="151" HEIGHT="54">
  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Ian
C. Dundas<BR>
President&nbsp;&amp; Chief Executive Officer<BR>
Enerplus Corporation </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-

REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-

<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_de16301_1_6"> </A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"black" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:arial;" -->
</FONT> <FONT SIZE=5>MD&amp;A </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=4>MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS 
("MD&amp;A") </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The following discussion and analysis
of financial results is dated August&nbsp;6,&nbsp;2015 and is to be read in 
conjunction&nbsp;with: </FONT></P>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT 
SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of Enerplus Corporation 
("Enerplus" or the "Company") as at and for the three and six months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 and 2014 (the&nbsp;"Interim Financial Statements"); 
</FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT
SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
audited consolidated financial statements of Enerplus as at 
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014 and 2013 and for the years ended 
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014,&nbsp;2013
and 2012;&nbsp;and </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-
11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT 
SIZE=2>our
MD&amp;A for the year ended December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014 (the&nbsp;"Annual 
MD&amp;A"). </FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
following MD&amp;A contains forward-looking information and statements. We refer
you to the end of the MD&amp;A under "Forward-Looking Information and 
Statements" for further information. The following
MD&amp;A also contains financial measures that do not have a standardized 
meaning as prescribed by accounting principles generally accepted in the 
United&nbsp;States of America ("U.S.&nbsp;GAAP"). See
"Non-GAAP Measures" below for further information. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>BASIS OF PRESENTATION  
</B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The Interim Financial Statements and 
notes have been prepared in accordance with U.S.&nbsp;GAAP including the prior 
period comparatives. All amounts are
stated in Canadian dollars unless otherwise specified and all other references 
relate to the notes included in the Interim Financial Statements. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Where
applicable, natural gas has been converted to barrels of oil equivalent ("BOE") 
based on 6&nbsp;Mcf:1&nbsp;BOE and oil and natural gas liquids ("NGL") have been
converted to
thousand cubic&nbsp;feet of gas equivalent ("Mcfe") based on 
0.167&nbsp;bbl:1&nbsp;Mcfe. BOE and Mcfe measures are based on an energy 
equivalent conversion method primarily applicable at the
burner tip and do not represent a value equivalent at the wellhead. Given that 
the value ratio based on the current price of natural gas as compared to crude 
oil is significantly different from the
energy equivalency of 6:1, utilizing a conversion on a 6:1&nbsp;basis may be 
misleading as an indication of value. Use of BOE and Mcfe in isolation may be 
misleading. All production volumes are
presented on a Company interest basis, being the Company's working interest 
share before deduction of any royalties paid to others, plus the Company's 
royalty interest unless otherwise stated. Company
interest is not a term defined in Canadian National Instrument&nbsp;51-
101&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;Standards of Disclosure for Oil and Gas Activities and may 
not be comparable to
information produced by other&nbsp;entities. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
accordance with U.S.&nbsp;GAAP, oil and gas sales are presented net of royalties
in our Interim Financial Statements. Under International Financial Reporting 
Standards, industry standard is to
present oil and gas sales before deduction of royalties and as such this 
MD&amp;A presents production, oil and gas sales, and BOE measures on this basis 
to remain comparable with our&nbsp;peers. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>NON-GAAP MEASURES  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The Company utilizes the following 
terms for measurement within the MD&amp;A that do not have a standardized 
meaning or definition as prescribed by U.S.&nbsp;GAAP
and therefore may not be comparable with the calculation of similar measures by
other&nbsp;entities: </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>"Netback"</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> 
is used by Enerplus and is useful to investors and securities analysts in 
evaluating operating performance of our crude oil and natural gas
assets. The term netback is calculated as oil and natural gas sales less 
royalties, production taxes, cash operating costs and transportation. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>6&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>

<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2 style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"> Oil and natural gas sales</FONT></TD>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Operating
costs adjusted to exclude non-cash gains on fixed price electricity swaps of 
$2.6&nbsp;million and $1.7&nbsp;million in the three and six months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 and $0.2&nbsp;million in both the three and six months 
ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2014. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>"Funds Flow"</B></FONT><FONT 
SIZE=2> is used by Enerplus and useful to investors and securities analysts in 
analyzing operating
performance, leverage and liquidity. Funds flow is calculated as net cash 
provided by operating activities before asset retirement obligation expenditures
and changes in non-cash operating working
capital. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>"Debt to Funds Flow 
Ratio"</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> is used by Enerplus and is useful to investors 
and securities analysts in analyzing
leverage and liquidity. The debt to funds flow ratio is calculated as total debt
net of cash, divided by a trailing 12&nbsp;months of funds flow. This measure is
not equivalent to Debt to Earnings
before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization and other non-cash charges
("EBITDA") and is not a debt&nbsp;covenant. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>"Adjusted Payout 
Ratio"</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> is used by Enerplus and is useful to investors 
and securities analysts in analyzing operating performance, leverage and
liquidity. We calculate our adjusted payout ratio as cash dividends plus capital
and office expenditures divided by funds&nbsp;flow. </FONT></P>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="45%" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=7 ALIGN="CENTER" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;"><B>Three months ended 
June&nbsp;30,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-

June&nbsp;30,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TD>

<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TD WIDTH="45%" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>Calculation of Adjusted Payout Ratio<BR> </B></FONT><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">($&nbsp;millions)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Cash
dividends exclude stock dividend plan proceeds in 2014. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In addition, the Company uses certain
financial measures within the "Overview" and "Liquidity and Capital Resources" 
sections of this MD&amp;A that do not have a
standardized meaning or definition as prescribed by U.S.&nbsp;GAAP and, 
therefore, may not be comparable with the calculation of similar measures by 
other entities. Such measures include "Senior
Debt to EBITDA", "Total Debt to EBITDA", "Total Debt to Capitalization", 
"maximum debt to consolidated present value of total proven reserves" and 
"EBITDA to Interest" and are used to determine the
Company's compliance with financial covenants under its bank credit facility and
outstanding senior notes. Calculation of such terms is described under the 
"Liquidity and Capital Resources" section of
this&nbsp;MD&amp;A. </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;7 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=8,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=784581,FOLIO='7',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DE16301A.;10',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_de16301_1_8"> </A>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>OVERVIEW  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our strong operational performance 
continued in the second quarter as we delivered production growth and met or 
exceeded all our guidance targets. As a result,
we are increasing our 2015 production guidance and lowering our operating cost 
and general and administrative ("G&amp;A") expense guidance by $0.65/BOE, 
combined. All other guidance targets
are&nbsp;maintained. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Average
daily production for the second quarter was 107,429&nbsp;BOE/day, exceeding our
annual average production guidance range of 97,000-103,000&nbsp;BOE/day. 
Production increased approximately
6,600&nbsp;BOE/day or 7% from the first quarter of 2015. The majority of the 
production growth was driven by our ongoing development in Fort Berthold, North 
Dakota, where production increased 26% or
approximately 5,600&nbsp;BOE/day compared to the first quarter. Natural gas 
production increased 6% from the prior quarter due to the ongoing development of
our Canadian deep gas properties and well
outperformance in the Marcellus. Based on our continued operational success, we 
are increasing our production guidance range to 100,000-104,000&nbsp;BOE/day and
expect approximately
44,000-46,000&nbsp;bbls/day of crude oil and natural gas&nbsp;liquids. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
maintained a disciplined capital program with spending of $148.0&nbsp;million in
our core areas during the quarter and are on track to meet our annual capital 
spending guidance of
$540.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Both
operating costs and G&amp;A expenses came in below guidance, at 
$76.7&nbsp;million or $7.85/BOE and $19.9&nbsp;million or $2.03/BOE, 
respectively. As a result of our continued focus on cost
control and increased production target, we are decreasing our operating cost 
guidance to $9.25/BOE from $9.75/BOE and our G&amp;A expense guidance to 
$2.25/BOE from $2.40/BOE, representing a combined
decrease of&nbsp;$0.65/BOE. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Funds
flow increased by 47% to $160.4&nbsp;million from $109.2&nbsp;million in the 
first quarter as a result of production growth and higher oil prices, along with
the impact of one-time expenses
experienced in the first quarter. Compared to the same period in 2014, funds 
flow decreased by
approximately $52.8&nbsp;million or 25% as oil and natural gas sales reflected 
the significant decline in commodity prices. Our hedging program provided 
additional revenue, generating gains of
$73.1&nbsp;million in the quarter compared to losses of $24.5&nbsp;million in 
the same period of&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Under
U.S.&nbsp;GAAP, we recorded a net loss of $312.5&nbsp;million for the quarter 
compared to net income of $40.0&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2014. The 
continued decline in the
twelve month trailing average commodity price resulted in an asset impairment of
$497.2&nbsp;million in the quarter. Year to date, we have recorded cumulative 
asset impairments of
$764.9&nbsp;million. We expect the twelve month trailing prices used to 
calculate impairment charges in accordance with U.S.&nbsp;GAAP to decline 
further, which may lead to additional write-downs
of our oil and natural gas properties in the second half of&nbsp;2015. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Despite
a decline in commodity prices during the first half of 2015 we remain in a 
strong financial position. At June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we were approximately 8% 
drawn on our $1.0&nbsp;billion
credit facility and had a conservative debt to funds flow ratio of 1.6x and 
senior debt to EBITDA ratio of 1.5x. After a US$10.8&nbsp;million senior note 
repayment due in the fourth quarter of 2015
we will have no term debt principal repayments due until June of 2017. We have 
added significantly to our hedging program during the quarter and continue to 
expect our risk management program to
protect our balance sheet and a portion of our funds flow in the second half of 
2015 and into&nbsp;2016. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS  
</B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Production  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Production for the second quarter 
totaled 107,429&nbsp;BOE/day, exceeding our guidance range of 97,000-
103,000&nbsp;BOE/day and increasing 7% compared to
100,855&nbsp;BOE/day in the first quarter of 2015. This increase was driven 
primarily by growth in our Fort Berthold production, which increased 26% or 
5,600&nbsp;BOE/day compared to the prior
quarter. We brought on 9.2&nbsp;net wells in Fort Berthold during the quarter 
compared to 3.6&nbsp;net wells in the first quarter. Based on our decision to 
accelerate the completion of eight
additional wells during the second half of 2015 we expect modest production 
growth in the region. Natural gas production increased by 6% from the prior 
quarter due to our ongoing development program
in the Canadian Deep Basin as well as continued well outperformance in 
the&nbsp;Marcellus. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Production
in the second quarter of 2015 increased by 3% from 103,987&nbsp;BOE/day in the 
same period of 2014 primarily due to an increase in Fort Berthold crude oil 
production. Natural gas
production remained relatively flat compared to the second quarter of 2014, with
growth in our Marcellus and Canadian Deep Basin production offset by the 
divestment of non-core Canadian natural gas
properties in the second half of&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>8&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_de16301_1_9"> </A>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our
production mix was unchanged from the previous quarter with crude oil and 
natural gas liquids accounting for 43% of our total average daily production. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Average
daily production volumes for the three and six months ended 
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 and 2014 are outlined&nbsp;below: </FONT></P>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As a result of continued 
outperformance we are revising our average annual production guidance upwards to
100,000-104,000&nbsp;BOE/day from our guidance of
97,000-103,000&nbsp;BOE/day provided in June. We expect annual production to 
include 44,000-46,000&nbsp;bbls/day of crude oil and natural gas&nbsp;liquids. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Pricing  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The prices received for our crude oil
and natural gas production directly impact our earnings, funds flow and 
financial condition. The following table compares
quarterly average prices from the second quarter of 2015 to the second quarter 
of&nbsp;2014: </FONT></P>

height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Before
transportation costs, royalties and commodity derivative instruments. 
</FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Crude Oil and Natural Gas Liquids 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>WTI crude oil prices increased by 19%
versus the previous quarter to average US$57.94/bbl during the second quarter of
2015. Although crude oil inventories in
the U.S.&nbsp;reached record levels of 491&nbsp;million barrels in April, strong
seasonal demand for gasoline and early indications of slowing crude oil 
production growth in the
U.S.&nbsp;resulted in inventory levels falling and WTI prices trading over 
US$60/bbl. However, increasing concerns over the Chinese economy and its 
potential negative impact on crude oil demand
growth, the nuclear agreement with Iran that will </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;9 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=10,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=157121,FOLIO='9',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DE16301A.;10',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_de16301_1_10"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>eventually
allow increased Iranian production to return to the market and the ongoing debt 
crisis in Greece all contributed to the decline of WTI to under US$50/bbl 
by&nbsp;mid-July. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
strength in WTI prices during the second quarter combined with improved realized
crude oil differentials resulted in a 32% improvement in selling price for our 
crude oil compared to the previous
quarter. Crude oil differentials in Canada strengthened considerably during the 
second quarter, due largely to scheduled oil sands maintenance and other 
unplanned outages from forest fires in Northern
Alberta reducing production. As a result, WCS differentials to WTI narrowed by 
US$3.14/bbl to average US$11.59/bbl below WTI and light sweet crude oil 
differentials in Canada narrowed by US$3.74/bbl
to average US$3.06/bbl below WTI. The strength in light sweet differentials 
helped support our Bakken differentials as well, which narrowed by US$2.35/bbl 
quarter over quarter to average US$9.30/bbl
below WTI during the second quarter. We expect both heavy and light oil 
differentials in Canada and the U.S.&nbsp;to widen for the rest of the year 
relative to the second quarter, as production is
stabilizing in the affected regions. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
decline in crude oil prices over the past twelve months and the level of natural
gas liquids production across the continent continues to depress North American 
natural gas liquids prices,
specifically propane. As propane production and inventories in Canada and the 
U.S.&nbsp;grow, it has resulted in negative benchmark prices for propane during 
May and June. However, stronger WTI
prices during the quarter helped stabilize market prices for butanes and 
condensate, partially offsetting the weakness in propane prices. Our realized 
price for our natural gas liquids production fell
by 7% quarter over quarter to average $20.88/bbl. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Natural
Gas </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Both AECO monthly index and NYMEX 
natural gas prices fell by 9% and 11%, respectively, versus the previous quarter
due to continued high production and
increased storage levels across the continent. U.S.&nbsp;dry gas production in 
June was approximately 3.0&nbsp;Bcf/day higher than last year while 
U.S.&nbsp;storage levels ended the quarter in
line with the five year average. Although production remains high, demand for 
natural gas fired power generation increased relative to previous years as 
natural gas prices were low enough to
incentivize generators to switch from coal to natural gas as a fuel for power 
generation. This increased power demand, combined with higher than expected 
exports from the U.S.&nbsp;to Mexico,
provided some price support by offsetting the continued strong North American 
production. However, even with the extra demand and normal weather, the strong 
production may push storage inventories to
test the upper end of capacity levels by the end of&nbsp;October. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
Western Canada, there were ongoing service interruptions and restrictions in 
certain areas of the NOVA Gas Transmission&nbsp;Ltd. ("NGTL") pipeline system as
TransCanada was
required by the National Energy Board to carry out thorough safety inspections 
of smaller diameter pipelines. These restrictions, combined with other unplanned
maintenance issues across the system,
have caused many producers in Western Canada to curtail natural gas production. 
Overall, we have been able to limit the impact on Enerplus through holding firm 
transportation in our key areas and
actively managing transportation shortfalls at affected locations. We had on 
average roughly 5&nbsp;MMcfe/day of natural gas production temporarily curtailed
during the quarter due to these
restrictions. We anticipate the curtailment of transportation services to ease 
somewhat before the end of the year, however, the issue may persist into 2016 as
further NGTL safety inspections
are&nbsp;required. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our
overall realized sales price for natural gas fell by 19% compared to the 
previous quarter to average $2.09/Mcf. This is in line with the combination of 
weaker NYMEX pricing and continued weakness
in the Marcellus producing region. While the average of spot market prices in 
Northeast Pennsylvania at the Transco Leidy and TGP Zone 4&nbsp;Marcellus were 
roughly unchanged from the first quarter,
outside of the northeast Pennsylvania producing region prices at Dominion South 
Point fell by 24% to average US$1.40/Mcf in the quarter. With approximately 37% 
of our Marcellus production tied to
markets outside the northeast Pennsylvania producing region that all realized 
wider differentials to NYMEX versus the previous quarter, our overall realized 
discount to NYMEX for our Marcellus
production widened by 5% or US$0.07/Mcf versus the first quarter to average 
US$1.39/Mcf. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Foreign
Exchange </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The Canadian dollar strengthened 
during the second quarter, increasing a modest 2% as a result of higher crude 
oil prices. Subsequent to the quarter, we saw the
Canadian dollar fall to a six year low USD/CDN exchange rate of 
1.30&nbsp;following the Bank of Canada's decision to cut interest rates by 
25&nbsp;basis points and lower their forecasted economic
growth for 2015. The majority of our oil and natural gas sales are based on 
U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated indices and therefore a weaker Canadian dollar 
relative to the U.S.&nbsp;dollar increases
the amount of our realized sales. Because we report in Canadian dollars, the 
weaker Canadian dollar also increases our U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated operating
costs, capital spending and the
principal and interest on our U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated senior&nbsp;notes. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>10&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT 
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=11,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=898861,FOLIO='10',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DE16301A.;10',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_di16301_1_11"> </A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"black" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:arial;" -->
</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>Price Risk Management  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We have a price risk management 
program that considers our overall financial position, the economics of our 
capital program and potential acquisitions. We
continued to add to our commodity hedge position in both 2015 and 2016 as a 
result of the modest improvement in crude oil prices during the quarter along 
with our decision to accelerate the
completions of eight additional North Dakota wells. For the second half of 2015 
we have an average of 11,250&nbsp;bbls/day of crude oil (approximately 35% of 
our expected crude oil production, net
of royalties) hedged at an average floor price of US$84.58/bbl through a 
combination of swaps and three-way collar structures. In 2016 we have an average
of 11,000&nbsp;bbls/day of crude oil
(approximately 34% of our expected crude oil production, net of royalties) 
hedged at an average floor price of US$64.35/bbl through a combination of swaps 
and three-way collar structures. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
continued to add to our NYMEX gas hedging program for 2015 and began hedging our
2016 gas production during the quarter. In the second half of 2015 we are 
swapped on an average of
128,370&nbsp;Mcf/day (approximately 47% of our forecasted natural gas 
production, net of royalties) at an average price of US$3.82/Mcf. In 2016 we 
have 25,000&nbsp;Mcf/day (approximately 9% of our
forecasted natural gas production, net of royalties) hedged through three-way 
collars with an average floor price of&nbsp;US$3.00/Mcf. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
following is a summary of our financial contracts in place at 
July&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2015 expressed as a percentage of our anticipated net 
production volumes: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Based
on weighted average price (before premiums), assumed average annual production 
of 100,000&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;104,000&nbsp;BOE/day for 2015 and 2016, less
royalties and production taxes of 21.0% in&nbsp;aggregate. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We have also entered into WCS and MSW
differential swap positions to manage our exposure to Canadian crude oil 
differentials. At July&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2015, we
have 4,000&nbsp;bbls/day of WCS swapped at US$(16.61)/bbl and
1,000&nbsp;bbls/day of MSW swapped at US$(3.50)/bbl in the second half of 2015 
and 2,000&nbsp;bbls/day of WCS swapped at
US$(14.50)/bbl in&nbsp;2016. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
have physically hedged a portion of our exposure to AECO differentials versus 
NYMEX prices through to October&nbsp;2019. These basis transactions are intended
to protect against weakening natural
gas prices in Alberta as increased production from the Marcellus is expected to 
flow into Ontario and the U.S.&nbsp;Midwest over the coming years. There is also
a risk of weaker AECO prices as a
result of continued growth in natural gas production in advance of potential 
Canadian west coast liquefied natural gas&nbsp;exports. </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;11 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In 2014 we entered into foreign 
exchange collars on US$24&nbsp;million per month to hedge a floor exchange rate 
on a portion of our U.S.&nbsp;dollar
denominated oil and natural gas sales with upside participation in the event the
Canadian dollar weakened. During the second quarter of 2015 we entered into 
U.S.&nbsp;dollar forward exchange
contracts on US$6&nbsp;million per month at an exchange rate of USD/CDN 1.20 to 
partially mitigate our losses on these collars. As of July&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2015, 
we effectively have
US$18&nbsp;million per month hedged for 2015 at an average USD/CDN floor of 
1.1088, a ceiling of 1.1845 and a conditional ceiling of 1.1263. Under these 
contracts, if the monthly foreign exchange
rate settles above the ceiling rate the conditional celling is used to determine
the settlement amount. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>ACCOUNTING
FOR PRICE RISK MANAGEMENT </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During the second quarter of 2015 we 
realized cash gains of $56.7&nbsp;million on our crude oil contracts and 
$16.4&nbsp;million on our natural gas
contracts. In comparison, during the second quarter of 2014 we realized cash 
losses of $21.2&nbsp;million on our crude oil contracts and $3.3&nbsp;million on
our natural gas contracts. The cash
gains in 2015 were due to contracts which provided floor protection above market
prices, while cash losses in 2014 were a result of prices rising above our fixed
price swap&nbsp;positions. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
the forward markets for crude oil and natural gas fluctuate and new contracts 
are executed and existing contracts are realized, changes in fair value are 
reflected as either a non-cash charge or
gain to earnings. At the end of the second quarter of 2015 the fair value of our
crude oil and </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>12&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT 
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=13,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=784617,FOLIO='12',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DI16301A.;9',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_di16301_1_13"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>natural
gas contracts represented net gain positions of $60.1&nbsp;million and 
$27.1&nbsp;million, respectively. For the three and six months ended 
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 the change in the
fair value of our crude oil contracts represented losses of $71.1&nbsp;million 
and $107.1&nbsp;million, respectively, and our natural gas contracts represented
losses of $21.8&nbsp;million and
$22.2&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During
the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we recorded total cash 
losses on our foreign exchange collars of $7.1&nbsp;million and 
$15.7&nbsp;million, respectively. At
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 the fair value of foreign exchange derivatives was a net
loss of $12.5&nbsp;million. See Note&nbsp;15 for further information.
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Revenues  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Oil and natural gas revenues for the 
three and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 were $298.4&nbsp;million and 
$542.5&nbsp;million, respectively,
compared to $504.5&nbsp;million and $999.6&nbsp;million for the same periods in 
2014. The decrease in revenue was driven by the weak commodity price 
environment, which saw benchmark prices decline
between 40% and 48% in the first half of 2015 compared to the same period 
in&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Royalties are paid to government 
entities, land owners and mineral rights owners. Production taxes include state 
production taxes, Pennsylvania impact fees,
freehold mineral taxes and Saskatchewan resource surcharges. During the three 
and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 royalties and production taxes 
decreased to $60.9&nbsp;million and
$110.8&nbsp;million, respectively, from $109.6&nbsp;million and 
$216.7&nbsp;million for the same periods in 2014, primarily due to lower 
realized prices. Royalties and production taxes averaged
20% of oil and natural gas sales before transportation in the first half of 2015
compared to 22% for the same period in&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
continue to expect an average royalty and production tax rate of 21% in 2015. 
</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As of January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2015 we 
have reclassified Marcellus gathering costs from operating expenses to 
transportation costs. These charges relate to
pipeline costs paid to third parties to transport saleable natural gas from the 
lease to downstream points of sale. This is a presentation change </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;13 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=14,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=744391,FOLIO='13',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DI16301A.;9',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_di16301_1_14"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>with
no impact on our netback, funds flow or net income. All comparative periods have
been presented to conform with the current period presentation. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Operating
expenses continued to trend lower as a result of our cost saving initiatives. 
For the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 operating expenses 
were $76.7&nbsp;million or
$7.85/BOE and $164.5&nbsp;million or $8.72/BOE, respectively, compared to 
$86.0&nbsp;million or $9.09/BOE and $165.9&nbsp;million or $9.03/BOE for the 
same periods in 2014. The decrease in
operating costs during 2015 compared to 2014 was primarily
due to realized cost savings in repairs and maintenance and well servicing, 
which were offset somewhat by the impact of a weaker Canadian dollar on our 
U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated operating costs. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on our cost savings realized to date and our increased production guidance we 
are reducing our 2015 guidance for operating expenses to $9.25/BOE from 
$9.75/BOE. Although year to date operating
costs are below our revised guidance, we anticipate an increase in operating 
costs during the second half of 2015 as a result of the seasonality of some 
spend and scheduled facility turnarounds. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As discussed previously in operating 
expenses, we have reclassified Marcellus gathering costs from operating expenses
to transportation costs. This is a
presentation change with no impact on our netback, funds flow or net income. All
comparative periods have been presented to conform with the current period 
presentation. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>For
the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 transportation costs were
$28.0&nbsp;million or $2.87/BOE and $54.5&nbsp;million or $2.89/BOE, 
respectively, compared to
$22.6&nbsp;million or $2.39/BOE and $45.0&nbsp;million or $2.45/BOE for the same
periods in 2014. The increase in transportation costs was due to higher 
U.S.&nbsp;production and the impact of a
weakening Canadian dollar on our U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated costs. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
are maintaining our transportation cost guidance of $3.00/BOE. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Netbacks  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The crude oil and natural gas 
classifications below contain properties according to their dominant production 
category. These properties may include associated
crude oil, natural gas or natural gas liquids volumes which have been converted 
to the equivalent BOE/day or Mcfe/day and as such, the revenue per BOE or per 
Mcfe may not correspond with the average
selling price under the "Pricing" section of this MD&amp;A. Certain prior period
amounts have been reclassified to conform with current period presentations. 
</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">See
"Non-GAAP Measure" in this MD&amp;A. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our crude oil properties accounted 
for 88% of our corporate netback before hedging for the first half of 2015 
compared to 71% for the same period in 2014. Crude
oil and natural gas netbacks per BOE decreased significantly for the three and 
six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 compared to the same periods in 2014 
primarily due to the decline in
commodity prices over the past twelve months. Realized cash hedging gains and 
lower royalty rates helped to offset the impact of lower&nbsp;prices. 
</FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;15 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=16,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=744104,FOLIO='15',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DI16301A.;9',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_di16301_1_16"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>General and Administrative 
Expenses  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Total G&amp;A expenses include cash 
G&amp;A expenses and share-based compensation ("SBC") charges related to our 
long-term incentive plans ("LTI&nbsp;plans") and our
stock option plan. See Note&nbsp;10 and Note&nbsp;14 for further details. 
</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Cash G&amp;A expenses during the 
three and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 were $19.9&nbsp;million or 
$2.03/BOE and $41.3&nbsp;million or
$2.19/BOE, respectively, compared to $18.7&nbsp;million or $1.97/BOE and 
$39.2&nbsp;million or $2.14/BOE for the same periods in 2014. The increase in
cash G&amp;A expenses from the prior year related
primarily to one-time severance payments of $2.5&nbsp;million during the first 
half of&nbsp;2015. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During
the quarter, our share price decreased by 15% resulting in a cash SBC recovery 
of $1.2&nbsp;million or $0.13/BOE compared to an expense of $10.7&nbsp;million 
or $1.12/BOE in the same period
of 2014. We recorded non-cash SBC of $4.6&nbsp;million or $0.47/BOE in the 
second quarter compared to $3.5&nbsp;million or $0.37/BOE during the same period
in 2014. The increase in non-cash SBC
was due to additional grants issued under the&nbsp;plans. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
have hedged a portion of the outstanding cash settled grants under our LTI 
plans. As a result of the decrease in our share price during the quarter we 
recorded a non-cash mark-to-market loss of
$1.0&nbsp;million on these hedges. As of June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we had 
524,000&nbsp;units hedged at a weighted average price of $16.51/share. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on our increased production guidance and continued focus on cost control, we are
reducing our 2015 guidance for cash G&amp;A expenses to $2.25/BOE from 
$2.40/BOE. We do not provide guidance for SBC
because it is dependent on our share price and our relative performance to 
our&nbsp;peers. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Interest Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>16&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT 
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=17,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=705859,FOLIO='16',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DI16301A.;9',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_di16301_1_17"> </A>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>For the three and six month period 
ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we recorded total interest expense of 
$16.1&nbsp;million and $33.2&nbsp;million,
respectively, compared to $16.5&nbsp;million and $31.7&nbsp;million for the same
periods in 2014. The increase in interest expense for the six month period 
corresponds to an increase in higher
interest rate senior notes following our September&nbsp;2014 private placement 
of US$200&nbsp;million and the impact of a weaker Canadian dollar on our 
U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated interest
expense. This was somewhat offset by senior note repayments of 
$88.9&nbsp;million in June funded by lower rate floating bank debt, along with 
an overall decrease in our drawn credit facility balance
following the receipt of net divestment proceeds of $187.8&nbsp;million during 
the second&nbsp;quarter. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Non-cash
amounts recorded in interest expense include amortization of deferred financing 
charges. See Note&nbsp;11 for further details. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>At
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 approximately 93% of our debt was based on fixed 
interest rates and 7% on floating interest rates, with weighted average interest
rates of 5.2% and 2.6%, respectively. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Foreign Exchange  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>For the three and six month period 
ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we recorded a net foreign exchange gain of 
$27.7&nbsp;million and a net foreign exchange
loss of $76.5&nbsp;million, respectively, compared to gains of $7.2&nbsp;million
and $5.8&nbsp;million for the same periods in&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Realized
losses in the second quarter included net payments of $7.1&nbsp;million on our 
foreign exchange collars and forward contracts along with losses on day-to-day 
transactions recorded in
foreign currencies. During the six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we 
recorded realized gains of $27.2&nbsp;million primarily due to a 
$39.9&nbsp;million gain on the unwind of our
US$175&nbsp;million foreign exchange swaps and losses of $15.7&nbsp;million on 
our foreign exchange collars. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Unrealized
gains and losses include the translation of U.S.&nbsp;dollar debt and working 
capital and unrealized gains or losses on our foreign exchange derivatives. See 
Note&nbsp;12 for further
details. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Capital Investment

<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=4 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=4 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Capital spending for the three and 
six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 totaled $148.0&nbsp;million and 
$315.0&nbsp;million, respectively, compared
to $204.4&nbsp;million and $422.2&nbsp;million for the same periods in 2014. 
Although spending has slowed in the first half of 2015 due to continued weakness
in commodity prices, we continued to
invest modestly in our core areas. During the second quarter we spent 
$110.6&nbsp;million on our Fort Berthold crude oil properties, 
$17.3&nbsp;million on our Canadian crude properties,
$12.6&nbsp;million on our Marcellus assets and $7.3&nbsp;million on our deep gas
properties in&nbsp;Canada. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During
the second quarter of 2015, we completed the sale of non-core assets for 
combined proceeds of $187.8&nbsp;million, net of closing costs, which includes 
the previously announced sale of our
Pembina waterflood assets. </FONT></P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;17 </B></FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=18,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=637054,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DI16301A.;9',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_di16301_1_18"> </A>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>There
were no acquisitions during the second quarter of 2015, although we recorded 
adjustments pertaining to prior period property acquisitions. In comparison, 
during the second quarter of 2014 we
spent $3.2&nbsp;million on minor property and land acquisitions. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Despite
the impact of the weakening Canadian dollar on our U.S.&nbsp;dollar denominated 
spending we continue to expect annual capital spending of $540&nbsp;million. 
</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>DDA&amp;A of property, plant and 
equipment ("PP&amp;E") is recognized using the unit-of-production method based 
on proved reserves. For the three and six months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 DDA&amp;A per BOE decreased when compared the same 
periods of 2014 primarily due to additional reserves recognized in the 
2014&nbsp;year-end reserves evaluation and the
effect of the previous impairment on our book&nbsp;value. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Impairment  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Under U.S.&nbsp;GAAP, entities using 
full cost oil and gas accounting are subject to a ceiling test performed on a 
country by country basis using estimated
after-tax future net cash flows discounted at 10% from proved reserves using SEC
constant prices ("Standardized Measure"). SEC prices are calculated as the 
unweighted average of the trailing twelve
first-day-of-the-month commodity prices. The Standardized Measure is not related
to Enerplus' investment criteria and is not a fair value based measurement, but 
rather a prescribed accounting
calculation. Under U.S.&nbsp;GAAP impairments are not reversible in 
future&nbsp;periods. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
trailing twelve month average crude oil and natural gas prices decreased 
significantly in the first half of the year, resulting in non-cash impairments 
of $497.2&nbsp;million and
$764.9&nbsp;million (before tax) for the three and six months ended 
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015, respectively. We did not record any ceiling test 
impairments on our oil and natural gas properties in
2014. We expect the twelve month trailing prices used in the ceiling test 
calculation to decline further which may lead to additional write downs of our 
oil and natural gas properties. See
Note&nbsp;5 for trailing twelve month prices and further information. 
</FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Asset Retirement Obligation  
</B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>In connection with our operations we 
incur abandonment and reclamation costs related to assets such as surface 
leases, wells, facilities and pipelines. Total
asset retirement obligations included on our balance sheet are estimated by 
Enerplus based on our net ownership interest, anticipated costs to abandon and 
reclaim and the timing of the costs to be
incurred in future periods. We have estimated the net present value of our asset
retirement obligation to be $282.5&nbsp;million at June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 
compared to $288.7&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014. The decrease is primarily due to the Pembina 
property divestment in the second quarter of 2015. Asset retirement obligation 
settlements for the three and six months
ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 totaled $2.6&nbsp;million and $6.5&nbsp;million, 
respectively, compared to $4.2&nbsp;million and $8.5&nbsp;million for the same 
periods in 2014. See
Note&nbsp;8 for further information. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Income Taxes  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We recorded a total tax recovery of 
$221.8&nbsp;million and $360.1&nbsp;million for the three and six months ended 
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015,
respectively, compared to a $16.5&nbsp;million and $48.7&nbsp;million expense 
for the same periods in 2014. The decrease in total tax expense is primarily due
to lower income in </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>18&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT 
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=19,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=82503,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DI16301A.;9',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_di16301_1_19"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>2015
which includes non-cash ceiling test impairments totaling $497.2&nbsp;million 
and $764.9&nbsp;million for the three and six months ended 
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015, respectively. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Given
the decrease in commodity prices and U.S.&nbsp;forecasted net income for the 
year, we expect current tax of less than 1% of our U.S.&nbsp;funds flow in 2015.
Our U.S.&nbsp;current tax is
comprised mainly of Alternative Minimum Tax ("AMT") payable with respect to our 
U.S.&nbsp;subsidiary. We expect to recover any AMT paid in future years as an 
offset to regular U.S.&nbsp;income
taxes otherwise payable. We do not expect to pay any cash taxes in Canada 
in&nbsp;2015. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
a result, an overall current tax recovery of $0.1&nbsp;million and nil has been 
recognized for the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015, 
respectively, compared to a
$3.8&nbsp;million and $11.5&nbsp;million expense for the same periods 
in&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>These
estimates may vary depending on numerous factors including commodity prices, 
capital spending, tax regulations and acquisitions and divestment activity. See 
Note&nbsp;13 for further
information. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>SELECTED QUARTERLY CANADIAN AND 
U.S.&nbsp;FINANCIAL RESULTS  </B></FONT></P>

interest volumes. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-
9pt;'><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(2)</FONT></DT><DD

transportation costs, royalties and the effects of commodity derivative 
instruments. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(3)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-

<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>20&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT 
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=21,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=336711,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DK16301A.;7',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_dk16301_1_21"> </A>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Oil and natural gas sales increased 
during the second quarter compared to the first quarter of 2015 as production 
volumes increased and oil prices improved.
From the first quarter of 2013, oil and natural gas sales increased steadily 
until the third quarter of 2014 when realized commodity prices began to decline 
significantly. Net income in the first half
of 2015 was impacted by asset impairments related to the decrease in the 
trailing twelve month average commodity prices used to calculate impairments. We
did not record any asset impairments in 2013
or&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES  
</B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>There are numerous factors that 
influence how we assess our liquidity and leverage including commodity price 
cycles, capital spending levels, acquisition and
divestment plans, hedging and dividend levels. We also assess our leverage 
relative to our most restrictive debt covenant, which is a senior debt to EBITDA
threshold of 3.5x for a period of up to six
months, after which it drops to 3.0x. At June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 our senior debt
to EBITDA ratio was 1.5x and our debt to funds flow ratio was 1.6x. The debt to 
funds flow ratio is often used by
investors and analysts to evaluate our liquidity, however, this measure is not 
part of our debt&nbsp;covenants. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Total
debt net of cash at June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 was $1,120.7&nbsp;million compared 
to $1,134.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014. Total debt was 
comprised of
$80.4&nbsp;million of bank indebtedness and $1,041.3&nbsp;million of senior 
notes less $1.0&nbsp;million in cash. At June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we were 
approximately 8% drawn on our
$1.0&nbsp;billion senior unsecured bank&nbsp;facility. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During
the second quarter, we repaid debt of $88.9&nbsp;million on the final maturities
of our US$40.0&nbsp;million and $40.0&nbsp;million senior notes. Following the
October&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2015 repayment of US$10.8&nbsp;million on our maturing 
US$54&nbsp;million senior notes, we have no scheduled debt repayments until June
of 2017, with remaining maturities
extending to&nbsp;2026. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our
working capital deficiency, excluding cash and current deferred financial and 
tax balances, decreased to $164.7&nbsp;million at June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 from 
$290.6&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2014. We expect to finance our working capital deficit 
through funds flow and our bank credit facility. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Our
adjusted payout ratio, which is calculated as cash dividends plus capital and 
office expenditures divided by funds flow, was 112% and 147% for the three and 
six months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015, respectively, compared to 120% and 119% for the same 
periods in 2014. We have continued to maintain our financial flexibility through
an ongoing focus on cost efficiencies
and the success of our non-core asset divestment program. After adjusting for 
net acquisition and divestment proceeds, our adjusted payout ratio for the six 
months ended June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015
decreases to&nbsp;75%. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>As
previously announced, in order to maintain our balance sheet strength we have 
reduced our monthly dividend by 44% to $0.05/share from $0.09/share effective 
with our March&nbsp;2015 dividend, paid
in April. Although we have revised capital spending guidance to 
$540&nbsp;million to accelerate North Dakota oil well completions, our overall 
capital spending budget remains 33% lower than 2014
spending levels. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
have a $1.0&nbsp;billion senior, unsecured, covenant-based bank credit facility 
that matures on October&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2017. Drawn fees range between 150 and 
315&nbsp;basis points over
Banker's Acceptance rates, with current drawn fees of 170&nbsp;basis points. The
bank credit facility ranks equally with our senior, unsecured, covenant-based 
notes. At June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015
we were in compliance with all covenants under our bank credit facility and 
outstanding senior notes. Our bank credit facility and senior note purchase 
agreements have been filed as material documents
on our SEDAR profile at <U>www.sedar.com</U>. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
following table lists our financial covenants as at June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015: 
</FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=22,EFW="2225646",CP="ENERPLUS 
CORPORATION",DN="2",CHK=1021813,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK132:
[15ZCB1.15ZCB16301]DK16301A.;7',USER='JATHANA',CD=';6-AUG-2015;16:56' -->
<A NAME="page_dk16301_1_22"> </A>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><U>Definitions</U> </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">"Senior Debt" is calculated as the sum of drawn amounts on our bank
credit facility, outstanding letters of credit and the principal amount of
senior&nbsp;notes. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">"EBITDA" is calculated as net income less interest, taxes, 
depletion, depreciation, amortization, accretion and non-cash
gains and losses. EBITDA is calculated on a trailing twelve month basis and is 
adjusted for material acquisitions and divestments. EBITDA for the three months 
and the trailing twelve months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 were $176.2&nbsp;million and $780.6&nbsp;million,
respectively. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">"Total Debt" is calculated as the sum of Senior Debt plus 
subordinated debt. Enerplus currently does not have any
subordinated&nbsp;debt. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;">"Capitalization" is calculated as the sum of total debt and 
shareholder's equity plus a $1.1&nbsp;billion adjustment
related to our adoption of U.S.&nbsp;GAAP. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><U>Footnotes</U> </FONT></P>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT  style="font-
size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Upon completion of a material 
acquisition, the Total Debt to Capitalization maximum ratio may increase to 55% 
for a period extending to and
including the second full fiscal quarter after the completion of the 
acquisition. </FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:arial;margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-
family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">Senior
Debt to EBITDA maximum ratio for the senior notes may increase to 3.5x for a 
period of 6&nbsp;months, after which the ratio decreases to&nbsp;3.0x. 
</FONT></DD></DL>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Dividends  </B></FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During the three and six months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we reported total dividends of $30.9&nbsp;million 
($0.15/share) and $78.3&nbsp;million
($0.38/share), respectively, compared to $55.2&nbsp;million ($0.27/share) and 
$110.1&nbsp;million ($0.54/share) for the same periods in&nbsp;2014. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Effective
with the April&nbsp;2015 payment, we reduced the monthly dividend by 44% from 
$0.09 per share to $0.05 per share to preserve our balance sheet strength. 
During the second quarter, our
dividends represented approximately 19% of our funds flow and at current levels 
we expect to spend approximately $124&nbsp;million annually on dividends, a 
decrease from $221.1&nbsp;million in
2014. Additionally, in September&nbsp;2014 we elected to suspend our stock 
dividend plan, thereby eliminating any dilution resulting from issuing shares as
part of our dividend&nbsp;plan. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
dividend is an important part of our strategy to create shareholder value and we
will continue to monitor commodity prices and economic conditions and are 
prepared to make adjustments
as&nbsp;necessary. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Shareholders' Capital

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>During the second quarter of 2015 a 
total of 45,000&nbsp;shares (2014&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;929,000) and 
$0.6&nbsp;million of additional
equity (2014&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$17.8&nbsp;million) was issued pursuant to the 
stock option plan and the currently inactive stock dividend plan. For the six 
months ended
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 a total of 492,000&nbsp;shares 
(2014&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;2,010,000) and $6.3&nbsp;million of additional equity
(2014&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;$36.7&nbsp;million) was issued pursuant to the stock 
option plan, the treasury settled Restricted Share Unit plan and the currently 
inactive stock
dividend plan. For further details see Note&nbsp;14. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>At
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we had 206,224,000&nbsp;shares outstanding 
(2014&nbsp;&#150;&nbsp;204,768,000) and at August&nbsp;6,&nbsp;2015 we had
206,224,000&nbsp;shares outstanding. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT  style="font-size:8pt;line-
height:9pt;"><B>22&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ENERPLUS </B></FONT><FONT 
style="font-size:8pt;line-height:9pt;">2015 Q2
REPORT</FONT></P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:arial;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_dk16301_1_23"> </A>
<BR>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>U.S.&nbsp;Filing Status  
</B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>Pursuant to U.S.&nbsp;securities 
regulations, we are required to reassess our U.S.&nbsp;securities filing status 
annually at June&nbsp;30. As at
June&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2015 we continued to qualify as a foreign private issuer for 
the purposes of U.S.&nbsp;reporting requirements. </FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2015 GUIDANCE  </B></FONT></P>
<P style="font-family:arial;"><FONT SIZE=2>We have increased our production 
guidance and have reduced our operating cost and G&amp;A expense guidance by a 
total of $0.65/BOE. All other guidance has been
maintained and is summarized below. This guidance does not include any 
unannounced acquisitions or&nbsp;divestments. </FONT></P>
<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
